text: The sign is illuminated. 2.        INT.  HAPPY'S RESTAURANT - NIGHT. Pretty, 30ish JOY JORDAN and teary-eyed STUART sit opposi
Good. Well. I had a really nice time.
Of course, you know I've always had a nice time with you.
'Cause you know I could never  hate you. At the same time, I just  don't think I could ever…you know… you.  In the way you should be…
Well. The food here was excellent– I'm gonna recommend it to my  sisters! How many stars did it get?
And the dam cracks wide open.  He bawls.  A pause.
It's really good we had this talk.
Before things went too far… You know, got too serious.
Yeah. I'm sorry. I'm too serious.
The thing is, I want to do what's right – for both of us.  I spent a lot of time…examining…my heart. And I felt that you deserved my honesty.
Now I just want to make you whole again.
…'Cause I was afraid we wouldn't be able to be friends anymore.
Oh, but you know how it is. And well, most guys…
I know. If only most guys were like you.
But then I'd be like most guys.
(laughs) Oh, Stuart. If only I felt the way I'd like to feel with you… Life is so unfair.  It's all my fault.
I want to show you something I got for you.
(hands her a gift) Open it up.
(discovers a pewter ashtray) Oh, but Stuart. This is…oh, this is beautiful.
Thanks. It's a Gainsevoort  reproduction. Boston, late 1800's. I sent away for it just after we had our…first date.
Oh, I just love it.  It's a…it's a collector's item.
(laughs) It almost makes me want to start smoking again!
Oh, Stuart. Thank you. This really means something to me. I'll always treasure it…as a token…

(retrieves his gift; a sudden shift in emotion:) 'Cause this is for the girl who loves me. The girl who cares for me, for who I am, not what I look like. I wanted you to know what you'd be missing. You think I don't appreciate art. You think I don't understand fashion. You think I'm not hip. You think I'm pathetic, a nerd, a lard-ass fatso. You think I'm shit. Well, you're wrong. 'Cause I'm champagne. And you're shit. And till the day you die, you, not me, will always be shit.
Thunder.  Rain.  STUART's car drives by. 4.        INT.  STUART'S CAR - NIGHT. JOY sits beside STUART, who is driving.  A plastic "World 5.        EXT.  JOY'S PLACE - NIGHT. The car pulls over.
JOY gets out.  STUART drives away. FADE TO BLACK. 6.        INT.  BILL'S OFFICE - DAY. ALLEN talks to his psychiatrist, BILL MAPLEWOOD.

…I dunno, but whenever I see her I just want to…you know…I want to undress her, I want to tie her up and pump her pump pump pump till she screams bloody murder. And then I want to flip her ass over and pump her even more and so hard my dick shoots right through her and so that my come squirts out of her mouth… Not that I could ever actually…do that… Oh, if only she knew how I felt, how deep down I  really cared for her, respected her, she would love me back. Maybe. But she hardly even knows I exist.  I mean, she knows I exist – we are neighbors, we smile politely at each other… But I don't know how I could ever begin to really talk to her, what can I talk about? I have nothing to talk about. I'm boring. I know. I've been told before, so don't tell me it's not true. 'Cause it's a fact. I bore people. People look at me and they get bored. They listen to me and they zone out, bored… And for her  to see how boring I am…no, no, no… It's better I say nothing… and hope… though right now, I have to say, if I were to suddenly jump out of my window, she wouldn't care. I mean, she'd care, of course, she'd care, I mean, she is human, but I mean she'd care the way you care about a stranger you read about in the paper that jumps in front of a running subway train, a stranger whose name you're never sure how to pronounce, if it's even printed. I'd be an anectode…maybe. But you know what I'm going to do? When I see her next time, as soon as I see her, I'm just going to tell her…tell her I find her…attractive. And that'll be that. Then…then we'll see…

HELEN parks, gets out of her car, walks towards the apart 8.        INT.  HIGH RISE LOBBY - EVENING. HELEN walks towards the elevator and waits beside ALLEN. ALLEN mumbles something.  HELEN is oblivious.
The elevator arrives. 9.        INT.  ELEVATOR - EVENING. ALLEN and HELEN step inside.  They ride in silence up to 10.        INT.  HALLWAY - EVENING. ALLEN and HELEN emerge from the elevator.

And they walk their separate ways. 11.        INT.  ALLEN'S APARTMENT - EVENING. ALLEN drops his stuff. He takes a shower. He lies down. He glances at a book of poetry.  CLOSE ON the jacket phot He leans his head against the wall, listens to HELEN maki He starts flipping randomly through the phone book.  He t

Who is this? ALLEN hangs up.  He buries his head in his hands. 12.        INT.  TRISH'S PLACE - DAY. JOY sits in the kitchen with her sister TRISH, who is doi Cute little TIMMY appears, in a Robocop-style outfit.
(aiming a laser at JOY) Die, Aunt Joy! Die!
She tries to go after him, but he has already run off.
Oh, leave him alone, Trish. He's just going through a phase.
(trying to make light) It's okay. I'm strong enough.
Oh, Joy, Joy. What's the matter?
I don't know what it is,  but I feel there's so much  hostility directed at me.
It's okay.  Because now maybe you'll listen to me.
You've got to eat red meat.
Oh, I knew that's how you'd react, but it's true. I've been watching you and, well… My doctor says just once a month…
Really. It's the best thing for the skin. It'll clear it all up.
It's fine now, but in another few years… Please, Joy. I'm speaking for your own good.
A tender moment: TRISH and JOY hold hands.
Being around you and the kids…
Oh… And I'm so happy you're happy. 'Cause all this time I've been thinking you were so miserable.
Oh, Trish! That's too funny, when I couldn't be happier.
It's just, what with your music career never really…
Oh, I know, it will be! I just know it! And then you'll move out of Mom and Dad's…
Oh, I will. Already I feel I'm off to a fresh start!
That's right. Just because you've hit 30, doesn't mean you  can't be fresh anymore.

You know, Joy, I've never told you this before, but now that we're older, and I feel so bonded to you, well…the truth is – oh, I know this sounds horrible, but I feel I have to be fully open with you, get beyond all the old barriers, sibling nonsense – well, the truth is I always thought  you would never amount to much. That you'd end up alone, without a career or anything. Really, it's what we all thought. Mom, Dad, Helen…everyone… I'd always prayed we'd all be wrong, but you had always seemed to…doomed to failure. But now I see, it's not true. There is a glimmer of hope for you after all. Oh, I know I'm repeating myself, but, oh…
(tears well up) I'm so happy for you…
It is sunny and warm.  Couples straight and gay walk hand BILL observes the pleasant tranquillity from atop a hill. Bloodshed everywhere.  Then silence.
BILL sits opposed his PSYCHIATRIST, to whom the VOICE bel
I don't kill myself at the end.
Do you see this as something positive?
How do you feel at the end?
Much better. I wake up happy. Feeling good. But then I get very depressed because I'm living in reality.
And you wouldn't kill people in real life.
My patients are ugly. Their problems are trite. Each one thinks he is  unique. On a professional level they bore me. On a personal level I have no sympathy. They deserve what they get.
No. But she's not too interested, either. So really there's no problem there, when you think about it, on a certain level.

BILL is driving along. 16.        EXT.  PARK - DAY. Reminiscent of BILL'S dream: schoolchildren are playing, BILL pulls up to the side of the field and observes from He gets back in his car. 17.        INT.  BILL'S CAR - DAY. BILL gets into the back seat of his car and sets to mastu SHOPPERS walk by with shopping carts, little children, ob Finally, BILL gets out of his car, tucks in his shirt, to 21.        INT.  BILL'S KITCHEN - EVENING. BILL comes home as Trish finishes preparing the dinner ta
So how was work today, Hon?
KOOKI calms down somewhat. BILLY ENTERS, opens the refrigerator, pours himself a sod
I don't wanna talk about it.
And he leaves for the TV room again.
Ignore him. He's just doing it for attention. He thinks you'll be impressed. As if. So anyway… Joy came by today.
Oh, God, I dunno, and frankly… I'm concerned. I mean, she's not like me. She doesn't "have it all." She pretends to be happy, but I can see right through her: she's miserable.
Why do you think that is?

To be frank, I think she's lazy. She's not a go-getter, like me or Helen.  And she's so picky. I gave Damien Ross her phone number, for  what it's worth, and Joy sounded interested, naturally, but…I dunno. I'm afraid to have to say it, but truly it's what I believe: she'll always be alone.
Oh, Bill. Sometimes I wonder how any of your patients can talk to you.
Sometimes I wonder if they'll ever stop. I should tape some for you.
Would you? Would you really? So that I could listen, too?
You're such a tease. You know I wouldn't tell anyone.
Well, maybe not as secretive as you.
What secret would you like me to tell you?
IRISH puts her arms around BILL.
(whispers coyly) Like how come no matter how much  you treat me like shit,  I can't help loving you even more?
While TRISH puts CHLOE and TIMMY to bed, BILLY comes and
Well, you know how sometimes your penis gets erect…well, sometimes it gets so excited that a sticky milky substance shoots out.
Yes, only come can be used as a verb as well.
Now Billy, it's alright if you haven't.
But everyone else in class had and… I want to come, too!
Awn, now, it's okay, it's okay. Have you tried playing with yourself?
I dunno. I don't know what to do.
Do you want me to…show you?
BILLY buries his head in BILL'S lap.
Aw, Billy. Don't worry.  You're normal. You'll come. One day. You'll see.
JOY is preparing to cook a steak.  She is wearing rubber
Y'know, people were always putting New Jersey down. None of my friends can believe I live here. But that's because they don't get it: I'm living in a state of irony.
Are you sure you don't wanna stay and have dinner with me?
I can't. I'm giving another reading/ book-signing over at Barnes & Noble, and then Jamal is taking me out – although I promised Fabiacho…Uch. Everybody wants me…
Yeah!… So, uh, how are you doing?
Oh, fine. Could you hold a second? Helen?
HELEN is almost out the door.
(into phone) Sorry. That was my sister leaving.
So, um, Trish told me you might  be calling.

Oh, I know how weird these things can be, but I've always had such faith in Trish's judgment that I thought why not. It's not like I've got some huge social life. I mean, I do have a social life. It's just not huge.
Oh, really? That's so nice to hear. Most people seem so confident…
Or, well, you know…  They're just real jerks.
Oh, I'm sorry, I'm just trying to thaw this steak…but it's so hard and… I'm sorry.
Oh, no. No. Don't stop. Not because of me.
Oh, but I feel I'm being so rude.
Oh, yeah. Don't worry. Nobody's listening in. God, you're just like me.
You mean, when we go out?  Well, where do you want to go?  I'm pretty easy to please.  I hate getting all dressed up.
Oh, just a pair of jeans. Why?
Not too tight. They fit okay. But why do you…?
I don't mean the jeans. I mean underneath. What are you wearing underneath? Check.
(starts looking inside her jeans) Underneath? Well, but Damien, underneath is just…
(pauses, suddenly alarmed) This isn't Damien…is it?
Are you getting wet? Is your pussy all—?

JOY hangs up. 24.        INT.  ALLEN'S BEDROOM - THAT MOMENT. VOICES of neighborhood children can be heard from outside ALLEN (the man behind the VOICE that was just on the phon He notices the mess he made on the wallpaper.  The stain The doorbell rings. ALLEN rises.
ALLEN opens the door, sees KRISTINA.  She is very big and
Did you hear what happened to Pedro?
He was found bludgeoned to death in his apartment this morning.
Yeah. And supposedly his penis is missing.
Yeah, well, Carla in 2B is collecting money for the funeral, if you feel like it. Apparently he had no family, no known friends…Gee, if I'da know… I mean, I did always say hi, I think.
Me too, if it's the guy I'm thinking of.
By the way, um, I've got an extra ticket to the play-offs tonight. Wanna come with me?
Nah. Thanks. I got too much work.
(a beat) Well, anyway, I just thought I'd tell you about Pedro.
And he closes the door. 25.        INT.  HALLWAY - THAT MOMENT. KRISTINA stands outside ALLEN'S door and stares at it dej
It is bright and sunny. 27.        INT.  CONDO - DAY. LENNY and MONA, in their 60s, sit at the kitchen table.
MONA rises, walks to her bedroom, lies down. LENNY clears the table.
And LENNY starts vacuuming up the debris on the floor. MONA goes to the bathroom, opens the medicine cabinet.
She has found a good enough valium substitute, but there The phone rings.
Oh, I'm fine. How are you?
Did you watch Leno last night?… Mom?
(she bursts into tears) He's leaving me!
Mom, what are you talking about?
Can you keep this secret? Top secret?
Yes, yes, of course, Mom, but –
He says…he doesn't love me anymore.
Mom, I'm sure he doesn't mean it.
Well, he does fucking mean it! He wants a divorce!
You don't believe me? Talk to him!
It's Trish! She wants to talk to you!
Is it true what Mom said?
(calling) Mona! What are you telling the kids? MONA comes wobbling into the room.
(hanging up; to MONA) Did I use the word divorce?
You said you didn't want to live with me anymore!
Answer my question: did I use the word divorce?
You said you didn't love me anymore!
Good. I just want that much clear. Now sit down now next to me.
Leave it. The machine'll get it. It's probably Joy.
(on the machine) Hi, Mom. Hi, Dad. It's Joy. Just called to say hi, but I guess you're out having a good time. Oh, well. I guess I'll talk to you tomorrow then. Okay. Bye.
I dunno. I just want to be alone.
But I can let you be alone more, if that's what you want.
Look: Things change… People change… Whatever. I want out.
You're in love with Diane Freed.
Well, you're in love with someone. Someone younger, probably.
Lenny, it's okay. I'm not dumb. These things happen. I'll get over it. I just wish you had done this twenty years ago. Now I'll have to get another fucking face-lift.
I'm in love with no one else.
The CAMERA DOLLIES across a maze of carrels, finally land

I'm sorry, I don't think so. But perhaps you're familiar with out—.

(a beat) I hope you fucking rot in hell.

(picking at her food) Uch. I don't know why I suggested this place. Joy recommended it…
Well, at least we're together. I never get to see you, you're so busy.
In fact, if I have to do one more  interview…
I guess it's hard, all this success.

It's just I'm so tired of…of being admired all the time. All these men… I mean, they're all beautiful, artistic minds, great sex, the whole package…but hollow, you know what  I mean? I feel nobody's really honest with me. Nobody wants me for me.
Oh, Trish. If only I had your husband, kids, carpool.
Well, I may "have it all," but sometimes I wonder what my life would have been like if I'd actually tried to write a novel.
Oh, I'm sure it would have been good.
No, I don't need that kind of success.
Uch, listen to us. We who have everything while Joy… What does she have?
You're right. And she's just getting older.
Last night she called – I was in bed with Vilmos – no, Huraki – and she was in tears. She told me she'd quit her job…
She said she wanted to "change" her life. Do "good" work with the poor, the needy…
Don't even try. She understand she already is good. She doesn't need to do good.
And what about her music career?
I don't know, but don't hold your breath. Anyway, listen. This is all top secret. She doesn't want anyone to know.
She felt she could trust me.
'Cause I always thought I was someone she could confide in.
A BUSBOY comes by, refills their water glasses, leaves.
Oh. I-I thought it was top secret.
Just for Joy. Sensitive Joy. Everyone else knows.
Can I help you with anything else?
The WAITER leaves the check, clears the plates, goes off.
Thanks for lunch. I really enjoyed this.

Well, that's up to Joe here.

You've come at a god time.  The place is in turmoil now. Everyone's preparing to strike.
W-why are they going to strike?

I can't tell you the half of it: the deceit, the corruption. The union wants to close down the school. They don't care about these poor immigrants. It's heartbreaking. Now I believe in unions, I'm sensitive to their needs, I cried at "The Grapes of Wrath", I sing to Woody Guthrie. But that was another time, another place. Today unions are just a new kind of corporation. It's tragic, but believe me, those teachers making sacrifices for the union, well, the union's not going to make any sacrifices for them. Those union leaders, they go home with pay-checks, the teachers end up with nothing. Now we need people who can be dedicated, who aren't in it just for the money. Because this job takes courage. Do you know what some of these refugees have endured? Concentration camps. And now their dream of coming to America is realized, and this union doesn't care. It's all about greed. Selfishness. Now Joy, can I count on you?
O-of course…I want to do the right, um, thing…I mean, I believe in, um, you know…being counted on…
Do you know what these strikers are? Spoiled brats. Trust-funded artistes. They don't know the meaning of work, of giving… But just remember, if you hear the word "benefits," don't listen.
